history.content:
CS70, ee126, ee127, math 110, math 104, cs189, CS182, cs170, should open the door for just about any ml grad course. 8 courses over 2 years and then you can jump into grad courses in ML/Stats here at Berkeley. 

---------------------------
Ok so there isn't a clean cut answer to this since ML is a relatively vast field and the requirements to do research in each sub-field differ quite a bit. What I would say is, EE126/127 and Math 104 are the bread and butter of ML research (but you need to take CS70 before them), and taking all of them will help no matter which direction you want to go to. EE126/127 are full of ideas that are fundamental to a lot of ML, but Math 104 (and preferably H104) builds the mathematical maturity to be able to use the ideas effectively. However take CS188-189 since combined they provide a pretty good overview of the range of possible things you can do in ML (primarily 188 for the basics of RL), but understand that they are for breadth and exposure to the topic, rather than depth of understanding. From there, pick the sub-field that interests you the most, and then plan accordingly. If you want to do RL, start emailing professors about research positions and go through resources on the content on your own. If computer vision is something that interests you, CS182 along with signal processing courses in the EE department are the way to go. The caveat to this is that if you want to do Stat ML (some of the more traditional material that you'd see in 189 for instance), you need to time things right since most graduate A/B courses happen on a fall-spring cycle. In addition, having Math 202A/B is really handy for mathematical maturity, and in conjunction with Stat 205A/B provides a rigorous foundation for thinking about probability and expectation (I remember the time where a page-long proof of a lemma in a paper simplified to 3 lines using measure theory), but the real courses you want to take are Stat 210A/B. After taking these 6 courses you'll have taken courses that a first year Stats PhD would have taken, putting you at a pretty good position to do research.

CS70, ee126, ee127, math 110, math 104, cs189, CS182, cs170, should open the door for just about any ml grad course. 8 courses over 2 years and then you can jump into grad courses in ML/Stats here at Berkeley.

children.subject: Is there actually no need to take any stats courses here at all before going into ML/stats grad courses?
Thanks!! I just don’t know which courses to take so having a list as a reference helps me a lot. Asides from stats 135/151A and the other answer above, do you have any other good recommendations?

If you were to add more courses other than those listed: math 105 for measure theory and then math 202a/b would be helpful for some grad level probability courses. Info 159 could be nice for applying some ml stuff to nap. Data100 is actually a real nice in between course for upper divs and a nice one to take with s hard course like ee126. It goes over programming, data cleaning, some ml algorithms like linear and logistic regression. Well run course that's a lot of breadth/data science internship skills. And you don't need data 8 for it. With that also keep your eye out for Interesting CS lower/upper divspecial topics courses. 

Same anon as original answer to post btw. Definitely also talk to some professors who teach here and are related to ML.

I second Data100! It was designed as like a bridge from lower div cs/ml/stat courses to 189 and I definitely felt it helped - the first lecture of 189 this semester was train/test/validation sets and I felt comfortable with the material due to the time Data100 spent on that subject. Data100 is also a nice workload for an upperdiv - I took it with 3 other techs in fall 2018 and felt it was reasonable. 

Math 104 (real analysis) was recommend to me if I wanted to pursue statistics grad school so it might be beneficial as well - really getting down into the foundations of math before you can prove other cool stuff. I have not taken it yet (will in fa19) so cannot speak to how much I enjoyed it/how well taught it was. 

Lastly, I am in EE127 (optimization models) this semester and I have actually been really enjoying the first few weeks. Gireeja Ranade and Alex Bayen have done a good job of reworking the course, and the first month is more linear algebra (which I love). If you like linear algebra, I'd recommend checking it out! It wasn't even on my radar till late last semester when I looked at the textbook and was like "this is kinda interesting!"

If you have some extra space in your schedule and want to check out some stat classes here are two that might be beneficial:

Stat135: Concepts of statistics

pro:goes really deep into maximum likelihood estimators, method of moments estimators, regression, and classic statistical concepts such as t-tests and f test etc

con: Goes into some topics that are less ml related like sufficient statistics, non-parametric vs parametric estimation, tests of homogeneity. 

I think it provided some interesting background on the core concepts of prediction and estimation, but the topics may not be enough to spend an entire semester on (unless you P/NP it)

Stat151a: Linear Modeling - Theory and Applications

This course goes deeper into regression and estimation, model selection, and multivariate data. 

again though it may not be worth to spend an entire semester when about half the topic related to ml. 

Lastly - they made a new class Stat157: intro to deep learning from the stats perspective (a counterpart to 182) but its taught by industry people this semester so not sure if its a permanent class.

As a side note - math110 was INCREDIBLY HELPFUL for building linear algebra intuition (especially if you enjoy the subject like I do). I didn't take EE16a/b but the combo of Math54 + Math110 made me feel very prepared for ee127 and cs189 this semester. I really enjoyed the class and highly recommend it. 

As a final note, while the courses listed by the student response cover most of the pure math needed starting with ml (in my opinion) its good to remember that ml is not pure cs - its a combo of math/cs/stats/lots of other things, and its nice to have some different perspectives from different disciplines. You're at berkeley - take advantage of the challenging and interesting courses offered here!

history.content: Current freshman who will have CS61A/B EE16A/B done by the end of this semester and multivariable calc from highschool. Not sure as to what math/stats/eecs classes I should take in the future to build maturity to take on ML grad level courses/research.
history.subject: What is a good list of courses that'll help me prepare for graduate level ML research?
